item.title: Masala bonds explained: Definition, features and benefits for issuers and global investors seeking rupee exposure

review.headline_rewrite: Masala bonds explained: Definition, features and benefits for issuers and global investors seeking rupee exposure
bullets: First introduced in 2014 through the International Finance Corporation (IFC), these unique bonds are rupee-denominated in nature and issued by Indian entities, permitting them
These bonds are issued outside the country but denominated in Indian rupees rather than the local currency of the country where they are issued.
On a fundamental level, Masala bonds are issued in foreign markets but are still payable in Indian rupees.
This method shields Indian conglomerates and companies from exchange rate volatility and ensures predictable repayment obligations in Indian rupees.
